verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 30:5
verses.text: Finding them deeply interested in Greek and Roman learning, he infused into them a love of philosophy, and led them to exchange their old zeal for the study of divinity.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 30:6
verses.text: Remaining with him five years, they made such progress in divine things, that although they were still young, both of them were honored with a bishopric in the churches of Pontus.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 31:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXI.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 31:2
verses.text: —Africanus.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 31:3
verses.text: At this time also Africanus, the writer of the books entitled Cesti, was well known.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 31:4
verses.text: There is extant an epistle of his to Origen, expressing doubts of the story of Susannah in Daniel, as being spurious and fictitious.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 31:5
verses.text: Origen answered this very fully.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 31:6
verses.text: Other works of the same Africanus which have reached us are his five books on Chronology, a work accurately and laboriously prepared.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 31:7
verses.text: He says in this that he went to Alexandria on account of the great fame of Heraclas, who excelled especially in philosophic studies and other Greek learning, and whose appointment to the bishopric of the church there we have already mentioned.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 31:8
verses.text: There is extant also another epistle from the same Africanus to Aristides on the supposed discrepancy between Matthew and Luke in the Genealogies of Christ.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 31:9
verses.text: In this he shows clearly the agreement of the evangelists, from an account which had come down to him, which we have already given in its proper place in the first book of this work.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 32:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXII.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 32:2
verses.text: —The Commentaries which Origen composed in Caesarea in Palestine.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 32:3
verses.text: About this time Origen prepared his Commentaries on Isaiah and on Ezekiel.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 32:4
verses.text: Of the former there have come down to us thirty books, as far as the third part of Isaiah, to the vision of the beasts in the desert; on Ezekiel twenty-five books, which are all that he wrote on the whole prophet.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 32:5
verses.text: Being at that time in Athens, he finished his work on Ezekiel and commenced his Commentaries on the Song of Songs, which he carried forward to the fifth book.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 32:6
verses.text: After his return to Caesarea, he completed these also, ten books in number.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 32:7
verses.text: But why should we give in this history an accurate catalogue of the man's works, which would require a separate treatise? we have furnished this also in our narrative of the life of Pamphilus, a holy martyr of our own time.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 32:8
verses.text: After showing how great the diligence of Pamphilus was in divine things, we give in that a catalogue of the library which he collected of the works of Origen and of other ecclesiastical writers.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 32:9
verses.text: Whoever desires may learn readily from this which of Origen's works have reached us.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 32:10
verses.text: But we must proceed now with our history.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 33:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXIII.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 33:2
verses.text: —The Error of Beryllus.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 33:3
verses.text: {{small-caps|Beryllus, whom we mentioned recently as bishop of Bostra in Arabia, turned aside from the ecclesiastical standard and attempted to introduce ideas foreign to the faith.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 33:4
verses.text: He dared to assert that our Saviour and Lord did not pre-exist in a distinct form of being of his own before his abode among men, and that he does not possess a divinity of his own, but only that of the Father dwelling in him.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 33:5
verses.text: Many bishops carried on investigations and discussions with him on this matter, and Origen having been invited with the others, went down at first for a conference with him to ascertain his real opinion.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 33:6
verses.text: But when he understood his views, and perceived that they were erroneous, having persuaded him by argument, and convinced him by demonstration, he brought him back to the true doctrine, and restored him to his former sound opinion.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 33:7
verses.text: There are still extant writings of Beryllus and of the synod held on his account, which contain the questions put to him by Origen, and the discussions which were carried on in his parish, as well as all the things done at that time.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 33:8
verses.text: The elder brethren among us have handed down many other facts respecting Origen which I think proper to omit, as not pertaining to this work.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 33:9
verses.text: But whatever it has seemed necessary to record about him can be found in the Apology in his behalf written by us and Pamphilus, the holy martyr of our day.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 33:10
verses.text: We prepared this carefully and did the work jointly on account of faultfinders.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 34:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXIV.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 34:2
verses.text: —Philip Caesar.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 34:3
verses.text: Gordianus had been Roman emperor for six years when Philip, with his son Philip, succeeded him.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 34:4
verses.text: It is reported that he, being a Christian, desired, on the day of the last paschal vigil, to share with the multitude in the prayers of the Church, but that he was not permitted to enter, by him who then presided, until he had made confession and had numbered himself among those who were reckoned as transgressors and who occupied the place of penance.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 34:5
verses.text: For if he had not done this, he would never have been received by him, on account of the many crimes which he had committed.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 34:6
verses.text: It is said that he obeyed readily, manifesting in his conduct a genuine and pious fear of God.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 35:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXV.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 35:2
verses.text: —Dionysius succeeds Heraclas in the Episcopate.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 35:3
verses.text: In the third year of this emperor, Heraclas died, having held his office for sixteen years, and Dionysius received the episcopate of the churches of Alexandria.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 36:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXVI.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 36:2
verses.text: —Other Works of Origen.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 36:3
verses.text: At this time, as the faith extended and our doctrine was proclaimed boldly before all, Origen, being, as they say, over sixty years old, and having gained great facility by his long practice, very properly permitted his public discourses to be taken down by stenographers, a thing which he had never before allowed.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 36:4
verses.text: He also at this time composed a work of eight books in answer to that entitled True Discourse, which had been written against us by Celsus the Epicurean, and the twenty-five books on the Gospel of Matthew, besides those on the Twelve Prophets, of which we have found only twenty-five.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 36:5
verses.text: There is extant also an epistle of his to the Emperor Philip, and another to Severa his wife, with several others to different persons.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 36:6
verses.text: We have arranged in distinct books to the number of one hundred, so that they might be no longer scattered, as many of these as we have been able to collect, which have been preserved here and there by different persons.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 36:7
verses.text: He wrote also to Fabianus, bishop of Rome, and to many other rulers of the churches concerning his orthodoxy.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 36:8
verses.text: You have examples of these in the eighth book of the Apology which we have written in his behalf.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 37:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXVII.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 37:2
verses.text: —The Dissension of the Arabians.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 37:3
verses.text: About the same time others arose in Arabia, putting forward a doctrine foreign to the truth.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 37:4
verses.text: They said that during the present time the human soul dies and perishes with the body, but that at the time of the resurrection they will be renewed together.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 37:5
verses.text: And at that time also a synod of considerable size assembled, and Origen, being again invited thither, spoke publicly on the question with such effect that the opinions of those who had formerly fallen were changed.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 38:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXVIII.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 38:2
verses.text: —The Heresy of the Elkesites.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 38:3
verses.text: Another error also arose at this time, called the heresy of the Elkesites, which was extinguished in the very beginning.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 38:4
verses.text: Origen speaks of it in this manner in a public homily on the eighty-second Psalm:  "A certain man came just now, puffed up greatly with his own ability, proclaiming that godless and impious opinion which has appeared lately in the churches, styled 'of the Elkesites.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 38:5
verses.text: ' I will show you what evil things that opinion teaches, that you may not be carried away by it.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 38:6
verses.text: It rejects certain parts of every scripture.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 38:7
verses.text: Again it uses portions of the Old Testament and the Gospel, but rejects the apostle altogether.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 38:8
verses.text: It says that to deny Christ is an indifferent matter, and that he who understands will, under necessity, deny with his mouth, but not in his heart.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 38:9
verses.text: They produce a certain book which they say fell from heaven.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 38:10
verses.text: They hold that whoever hears and believes this shall receive remission of sins, another remission than that which Jesus Christ has given".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 38:11
verses.text: Such is the account of these persons.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 39:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXIX.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 39:2
verses.text: —The Persecution under Decius, and the Sufferings of Origen.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 39:3
verses.text: After a reign of seven years Philip was succeeded by Decius.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 39:4
verses.text: On account of his hatred of Philip, he commenced a persecution of the churches, in which Fabianus suffered martyrdom at Rome, and Cornelius succeeded him in the episcopate.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 39:5
verses.text: In Palestine, Alexander, bishop of the church of Jerusalem, was brought again on Christ's account before the governor's judgment seat in Caesarea, and having acquitted himself nobly in a second confession was cast into prison, crowned with the hoary locks of venerable age.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 39:6
verses.text: And after his honorable and illustrious confession at the tribunal of the governor, he fell asleep in prison, and Mazabanes became his successor in the bishopric of Jerusalem.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 39:7
verses.text: Babylas in Antioch, having like Alexander passed away in prison after his confession, was succeeded by Fabius in the episcopate of that church.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 39:8
verses.text: But how many and how great things came upon Origen in the persecution, and what was their final result,—as the demon of evil marshaled all his forces, and fought against the man with his utmost craft and power, assaulting him beyond all others against whom he contended at that time,—and what and how many things he endured for the word of Christ, bonds and bodily tortures and torments under the iron collar and in the dungeon; and how for many days with his feet stretched four spaces in the stocks he bore patiently the threats of fire and whatever other things were inflicted by his enemies; and how his sufferings terminated, as his judge strove eagerly with all his might not to end his life; and what words he left after these things, full of comfort to those needing aid, a great many of his epistles show with truth and accuracy.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 40:1
verses.text: Chapter XL.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 40:2
verses.text: —The Events which happened to Dionysius.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 40:3
verses.text: I shall quote from the epistle of Dionysius to Germanus an account of what befell the former.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 40:4
verses.text: Speaking of himself, he writes as follows: "I speak before God, and he knows that I do not lie.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 40:5
verses.text: I did not flee on my own impulse nor without divine direction.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 40:6
verses.text: But even before this, at the very hour when the Decian persecution was commanded, Sabinus sent a frumentarius to search for me, and I remained at home four days awaiting his arrival.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 40:7
verses.text: But he went about examining all places,—roads, rivers, and fields,—where he thought I might be concealed or on the way.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 40:8
verses.text: But he was smitten with blindness, and did not find the house, for he did not suppose, that being pursued, I would remain at home.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 40:9
verses.text: And after the fourth day God commanded me to depart, and made a way for me in a wonderful manner; and I and my attendants and many of the brethren went away together.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 40:10
verses.text: And that this occurred through the providence of God was made manifest by what followed, in which perhaps we were useful to some".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 40:11
verses.text: Farther on he relates in this manner what happened to him after his flight:  "For about sunset, having been seized with those that were with me, I was taken by the soldiers to Taposiris, but in the providence of God, Timothy was not present and was not captured.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 40:12
verses.text: But coming later, he found the house deserted and guarded by soldiers, and ourselves reduced to slavery".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 40:13
verses.text: After a little he says:  "And what was the manner of his admirable management? for the truth shall be told.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 40:14
verses.text: One of the country people met Timothy fleeing and disturbed, and inquired the cause of his haste.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 40:15
verses.text: And he told him the truth.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 40:16
verses.text: And when the man heard it (he was on his way to a marriage feast, for it was customary to spend the entire night in such gatherings), he entered and announced it to those at the table.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 40:17
verses.text: And they, as if on a preconcerted signal, arose with one impulse, and rushed out quickly and came and burst in upon us with a shout.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 40:18
verses.text: Immediately the soldiers who were guarding us fled, and they came to us lying as we were upon the bare couches.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 40:19
verses.text: But I, God knows, thought at first that they were robbers who had come for spoil and plunder.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 40:20
verses.text: So I remained upon the bed on which I was, clothed only in a linen garment, and offered them the rest of my clothing which was lying beside me.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 40:21
verses.text: But they directed me to rise and come away quickly.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 40:22
verses.text: Then I understood why they were come, and I cried out, beseeching and entreating them to depart and leave us alone.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 40:23
verses.text: And I requested them, if they desired to benefit me in any way, to anticipate those who were carrying me off, and cut off my head themselves.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 40:24
verses.text: And when I had cried out in this manner, as my companions and partners in everything know, they raised me by force.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 40:25
verses.text: But I threw myself on my back on the ground; and they seized me by the hands and feet and dragged me away.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 40:26
verses.text: And the witnesses of all these occurrences followed: Gaius, Faustus, Peter, and Paul.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 40:27
verses.text: But they who had seized me carried me out of the village hastily, and placing me on an ass without a saddle, bore me away".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 40:28
verses.text: Dionysius relates these things respecting himself.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:1
verses.text: Chapter XLI.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:2
verses.text: —The Martyrs in Alexandria.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:3
verses.text: The same writer, in an epistle to Fabius, bishop of Antioch, relates as follows the sufferings of the martyrs in Alexandria under Decius:  "The persecution among us did not begin with the royal decree, but preceded it an entire year.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:4
verses.text: The prophet and author of evils to this city, whoever he was, previously moved and aroused against us the masses of the heathen, rekindling among them the superstition of their country.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:5
verses.text: And being thus excited by him and finding full opportunity for any wickedness, they considered this the only pious service of their demons, that they should slay us.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:6
verses.text: "They seized first an old man named Metras, and commanded him to utter impious words.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:7
verses.text: But as he would not obey, they beat him with clubs, and tore his face and eyes with sharp sticks, and dragged him out of the city and stoned him.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:8
verses.text: Then they carried to their idol temple a faithful woman, named Quinta, that they might force her to worship.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:9
verses.text: And as she turned away in detestation, they bound her feet and dragged her through the entire city over the stone-paved streets, and dashed her against the millstones, and at the same time scourged her; then, taking her to the same place, they stoned her to death.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:10
verses.text: Then all with one impulse rushed to the homes of the pious, and they dragged forth whomsoever any one knew as a neighbor, and despoiled and plundered them.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:11
verses.text: They took for themselves the more valuable property; but the poorer articles and those made of wood they scattered about and burned in the streets, so that the city appeared as if taken by an enemy.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:12
verses.text: But the brethren withdrew and went away, and 'took joyfully the spoiling of their goods,' like those to whom Paul bore witness.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:13
verses.text: I know of no one unless possibly some one who fell into their hands, who, up to this time, denied the Lord.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:14
verses.text: Then they seized also that most admirable virgin, Apollonia, an old woman, and, smiting her on the jaws, broke out all her teeth.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:15
verses.text: And they made a fire outside the city and threatened to burn her alive if she would not join with them in their impious cries.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:16
verses.text: And she, supplicating a little, was released, when she leaped eagerly into the fire and was consumed.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:17
verses.text: Then they seized Serapion in his own house, and tortured him with harsh cruelties, and having broken all his limbs, they threw him headlong from an upper story.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:18
verses.text: And there was no street, nor public road, nor lane open to us, by night or day; for always and everywhere, all of them cried out that if any one would not repeat their impious words, he should immediately be dragged away and burned.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:19
verses.text: And matters continued thus for a considerable time.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:20
verses.text: But a sedition and civil war came upon the wretched people and turned their cruelty toward us against one another.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:21
verses.text: So we breathed for a little while as they ceased from their rage against us.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:22
verses.text: But presently the change from that milder reign was announced to us, and great fear of what was threatened seized us.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:23
verses.text: For the decree arrived, almost like unto that most terrible time foretold by our Lord, which if it were possible would offend even the elect.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:24
verses.text: All truly were affrighted.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:25
verses.text: And many of the more eminent in their fear came forward immediately; others who were in the public service were drawn on by their official duties; others were urged on by their acquaintances.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:26
verses.text: And as their names were called they approached the impure and impious sacrifices.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:27
verses.text: Some of them were pale and trembled as if they were not about to sacrifice, but to be themselves sacrifices and offerings to the idols; so that they were jeered at by the multitude who stood around, as it was plain to every one that they were afraid either to die or to sacrifice.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:28
verses.text: But some advanced to the altars more readily, declaring boldly that they had never been Christians.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:29
verses.text: Of these the prediction of our Lord is most true that they shall 'hardly' be saved.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:30
verses.text: Of the rest some followed the one, others the other of these classes, some fled and some were seized.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:31
verses.text: And of the latter some continued faithful until bonds and imprisonment, and some who had even been imprisoned for many days yet abjured the faith before they were brought to trial.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:32
verses.text: Others having for a time endured great tortures finally retracted.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:33
verses.text: But the firm and blessed pillars of the Lord being strengthened by him, and having received vigor and might suitable and appropriate to the strong faith which they possessed, became admirable witnesses of his kingdom.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:34
verses.text: The first of these was Julian, a man who suffered so much with the gout that he was unable to stand or walk.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:35
verses.text: They brought him forward with two others who carried him.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:36
verses.text: One of these immediately denied.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:37
verses.text: But the other, whose name was Cronion, and whose surname was Eunus, and the old man Julian himself, both of them having confessed the Lord, were carried on camels through the entire city, which, as you know, is a very large one, and in this elevated position were beaten and finally burned in a fierce fire, surrounded by all the populace.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:38
verses.text: But a soldier, named Besas, who stood by them as they were led away rebuked those who insulted them.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:39
verses.text: And they cried out against him, and this most manly warrior of God was arraigned, and having done nobly in the great contest for piety, was beheaded.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:40
verses.text: A certain other one, a Libyan by birth, but in name and blessedness a true Macar, was strongly urged by the judge to recant; but as he would not yield he was burned alive.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:41
verses.text: After them Epimachus and Alexander, having remained in bonds for a long time, and endured countless agonies from scrapers and scourges, were also consumed in a fierce fire.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:42
verses.text: And with them there were four women.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:43
verses.text: Ammonarium, a holy virgin, the judge tortured relentlessly and excessively, because she declared from the first that she would utter none of those things which he commanded; and having kept her promise truly, she was dragged away.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:44
verses.text: The others were Mercuria, a very remarkable old woman, and Dionysia, the mother of many children, who did not love her own children above the Lord.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:45
verses.text: As the governor was ashamed of torturing thus ineffectually, and being always defeated by women, they were put to death by the sword, without the trial of tortures.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:46
verses.text: For the champion, Ammonarium, endured these in behalf of all.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:47
verses.text: The Egyptians, Heron and Ater and Isidorus, and with them Dioscorus, a boy about fifteen years old, were delivered up.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:48
verses.text: At first the judge attempted to deceive the lad by fair words, as if he could be brought over easily, and then to force him by tortures, as one who would readily yield.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:49
verses.text: But Dioscorus was neither persuaded nor constrained.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:50
verses.text: As the others remained firm, he scourged them cruelly and then delivered them to the fire.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:51
verses.text: But admiring the manner in which Dioscorus had distinguished himself publicly, and his wise answers to his persuasions, he dismissed him, saying that on account of his youth he would give him time for repentance.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:52
verses.text: And this most godly Dioscorus is among us now, awaiting a longer conflict and more severe contest.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:53
verses.text: But a certain Nemesion, who also was an Egyptian, was accused as an associate of robbers; but when he had cleared himself before the centurion of this charge most foreign to the truth, he was informed against as a Christian, and taken in bonds before the governor.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:54
verses.text: And the most unrighteous magistrate inflicted on him tortures and scourgings double those which he executed on the robbers, and then burned him between the robbers, thus honoring the blessed man by the likeness to Christ.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:55
verses.text: A band of soldiers, Ammon and Zeno and Ptolemy and Ingenes, and with them an old man, Theophilus, were standing close together before the tribunal.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:56
verses.text: And as a certain person who was being tried as a Christian, seemed inclined to deny, they standing by gnashed their teeth, and made signs with their faces and stretched out their hands, and gestured with their bodies.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:57
verses.text: And when the attention of all was turned to them, before any one else could seize them, they rushed up to the tribunal saying that they were Christians, so that the governor and his council were affrighted.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:58
verses.text: And those who were on trial appeared most courageous in prospect of their sufferings, while their judges trembled.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 41:59
verses.text: And they went exultingly from the tribunal rejoicing in their testimony; God himself having caused them to triumph gloriously".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 42:1
verses.text: Chapter XLII.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 42:2
verses.text: —Others of whom Dionysius gives an Account.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 42:3
verses.text: "Many others, in cities and villages, were torn asunder by the heathen, of whom I will mention one as an illustration.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 42:4
verses.text: Ischyrion was employed as a steward by one of the rulers.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 42:5
verses.text: His employer commanded him to sacrifice, and on his refusal insulted him, and as he remained firm, abused him.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 42:6
verses.text: And as he still held out he seized a long staff and thrust it through his bowels and slew him.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 42:7
verses.text: "Why need I speak of the multitude that wandered in the deserts and mountains, and perished by hunger, and thirst, and cold, and sickness, and robbers, and wild beasts? Those of them who survived are witnesses of their election and victory.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 42:8
verses.text: But I will relate one occurrence as an example.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 42:9
verses.text: Chaeremon, who was very old, was bishop of the city called Nilus.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 42:10
verses.text: He fled with his wife to the Arabian mountain and did not return.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 42:11
verses.text: And though the brethren searched diligently they could not find either them or their bodies.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 42:12
verses.text: And many who fled to the same Arabian mountain were carried into slavery by the barbarian Saracens.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 42:13
verses.text: Some of them were ransomed with difficulty and at a large price; others have not been to the present time.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 42:14
verses.text: I have related these things, my brother, not without an object, but that you may understand how many and great distresses came upon us.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 42:15
verses.text: Those indeed will understand them the best who have had the largest experience of them".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 42:16
verses.text: A little further on he adds: "These divine martyrs among us, who now are seated with Christ, and are sharers in his kingdom, partakers of his judgment and judges with him, received some of the brethren who had fallen away and become chargeable with the guilt of sacrificing.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 42:17
verses.text: When they perceived that their conversion and repentance were sufficient to be acceptable with him who by no means desires the death of the sinner, but his repentance, having proved them they received them back and brought them together, and met with them and had fellowship with them in prayers and feasts.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 42:18
verses.text: What counsel then, brethren, do you give us concerning such persons? What should we do? Shall we have the same judgment and rule as theirs, and observe their decision and charity, and show mercy to those whom they pitied? Or, shall we declare their decision unrighteous, and set ourselves as judges of their opinion, and grieve mercy and overturn order?" These words Dionysius very properly added when making mention of those who had been weak in the time of persecution.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 43:1
verses.text: Chapter XLIII.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 43:2
verses.text: —Novatus, his Manner of Life and his Heresy.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 43:3
verses.text: After this, Novatus, a presbyter of the church at Rome, being lifted up with arrogance against these persons, as if there was no longer for them a hope of salvation, not even if they should do all things pertaining to a genuine and pure conversion, became leader of the heresy of those who, in the pride of their imagination, call themselves Cathari.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 43:4
verses.text: There upon a very large synod assembled at Rome, of bishops in number sixty, and a great many more presbyters and deacons; while the pastors of the remaining provinces deliberated in their places privately concerning what ought to be done.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 43:5
verses.text: A decree was confirmed by all, that Novatus and those who joined with him, and those who adopted his brother-hating and inhuman opinion, should be considered by the church as strangers; but that they should heal such of the brethren as had fallen into misfortune, and should minister to them with the medicines of repentance.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 43:6
verses.text: There have reached us epistles of Cornelius, bishop of Rome, to Fabius, of the church at Antioch, which show what was done at the synod at Rome, and what seemed best to all those in Italy and Africa and the regions thereabout.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 43:7
verses.text: Also other epistles, written in the Latin language, of Cyprian and those with him in Africa, which show that they agreed as to the necessity of succoring those who had been tempted, and of cutting off from the Catholic Church the leader of the heresy and all that joined with him.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 43:8
verses.text: Another epistle of Cornelius, concerning the resolutions of the synod, is attached to these; and yet others, on the conduct of Novatus, from which it is proper for us to make selections, that any one who sees this work may know about him.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 43:9
verses.text: Cornelius informs Fabius what sort of a man Novatus was, in the following words:  "But that you may know that a long time ago this remarkable man desired the episcopate, but kept this ambitious desire to himself and concealed it,—using as a cloak for his rebellion those confessors who had adhered to him from the beginning,—I desire to speak.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 43:10
verses.text: Maximus, one of our presbyters, and Urbanus, who twice gained the highest honor by confession, with Sidonius, and Celerinus, a man who by the grace of God most heroically endured all kinds of torture, and by the strength of his faith overcame the weakness of the flesh, and mightily conquered the adversary,—these men found him out and detected his craft and duplicity, his perjuries and falsehoods, his unsociability and cruel friendship.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 43:11
verses.text: And they returned to the holy church and proclaimed in the presence of many, both bishops and presbyters and a large number of the laity, all his craft and wickedness, which for a long time he had concealed.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 43:12
verses.text: And this they did with lamentations and repentance, because through the persuasions of the crafty and malicious beast they had left the church for the time".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 43:13
verses.text: A little farther on he says:.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 43:14
verses.text: "How remarkable, beloved brother, the change and transformation which we have seen take place in him in a short time.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 43:15
verses.text: For this most illustrious man, who bound himself with terrible oaths in nowise to seek the bishopric, suddenly appears a bishop as if thrown among us by some machine.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 43:16
verses.text: For this dogmatist, this defender of the doctrine of the Church, attempting to grasp and seize the episcopate, which had not been given him from above, chose two of his companions who had given up their own salvation.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 43:17
verses.text: And he sent them to a small and insignificant corner of Italy, that there by some counterfeit argument he might deceive three bishops, who were rustic and very simple men.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 43:18
verses.text: And they asserted positively and strongly that it was necessary that they should come quickly to Rome, in order that all the dissension which had arisen there might be appeased through their mediation, jointly with other bishops.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 43:19
verses.text: When they had come, being, as we have stated, very simple in the craft and artifice of the wicked, they were shut up with certain selected men like himself.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 43:20
verses.text: And by the tenth hour, when they had become drunk and sick, he compelled them by force to confer on him the episcopate through a counterfeit and vain imposition of hands.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 43:21
verses.text: Because it had not come to him, he avenged himself by craft and treachery.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 43:22
verses.text: One of these bishops shortly after came back to the church, lamenting and confessing his transgression.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 43:23
verses.text: And we communed with him as with a layman, all the people present interceding for him.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 43:24
verses.text: And we ordained successors of the other bishops, and sent them to the places where they were.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 43:25
verses.text: This avenger of the Gospel then did not know that there should be one bishop in a catholic church; yet he was not ignorant (for how could he be?) that in it there were forty-six presbyters, seven deacons, seven sub-deacons, forty-two acolyths, fifty-two exorcists, readers, and janitors, and over fifteen hundred widows and persons in distress, all of whom the grace and kindness of the Master nourish.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 43:26
verses.text: But not even this great multitude, so necessary in the church, nor those who, through God's providence, were rich and full, together with the very many, even innumerable people, could turn him from such desperation and presumption and recall him to the Church".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 43:27
verses.text: Again, farther on, he adds these words: "Permit us to say further: On account of what works or conduct had he the assurance to contend for the episcopate? Was it that he had been brought up in the Church from the beginning, and had endured many conflicts in her behalf, and had passed through many and great dangers for religion? Truly this is not the fact.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 43:28
verses.text: But Satan, who entered and dwelt in him for a long time, became the occasion of his believing.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 43:29
verses.text: Being delivered by the exorcists, he fell into a severe sickness; and as he seemed about to die, he received baptism by affusion, on the bed where he lay; if indeed we can say that such a one did receive it.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 43:30
verses.text: And when he was healed of his sickness he did not receive the other things which it is necessary to have according to the canon of the Church, even the being sealed by the bishop.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 43:31
verses.text: And as he did not receive this, how could he receive the Holy Spirit?".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 43:32
verses.text: Shortly after he says again:  "In the time of persecution, through cowardice and love of life, he denied that he was a presbyter.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 43:33
verses.text: For when he was requested and entreated by the deacons to come out of the chamber in which he had imprisoned himself and give aid to the brethren as far as was lawful and possible for a presbyter to assist those of the brethren who were in danger and needed help, he paid so little respect to the entreaties of the deacons that he went away and departed in anger.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 43:34
verses.text: For he said that he no longer desired to be a presbyter, as he was an admirer of another philosophy".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 43:35
verses.text: Passing by a few things, he adds the following:  "For this illustrious man forsook the Church of God, in which, when he believed, he was judged worthy of the presbyterate through the favor of the bishop who ordained him to the presbyterial office.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 43:36
verses.text: This had been resisted by all the clergy and many of the laity; because it was unlawful that one who had been affused on his bed on account of sickness as he had been should enter into any clerical office; but the bishop requested that he might be permitted to ordain this one only".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 43:37
verses.text: He adds to these yet another, the worst of all the man's offenses, as follows:  "For when he has made the offerings, and distributed a part to each man, as he gives it he compels the wretched man to swear in place of the blessing.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 43:38
verses.text: Holding his hands in both of his own, he will not release him until he has sworn in this manner (for I will give his own words):  'Swear to me by the body and blood of our Lord Jesus Christ that you will never forsake me and turn to Cornelius.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 43:40
verses.text: And the unhappy man does not taste until he has called down imprecations on himself; and instead of saying Amen, as he takes the bread, he says, I will never return to Cornelius".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 43:41
verses.text: Farther on he says again:.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 43:42
verses.text: "But know that he has now been made bare and desolate; as the brethren leave him every day and return to the church.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 43:43
verses.text: Moses also, the blessed martyr, who lately suffered among us a glorious and admirable martyrdom, while he was yet alive, beholding his boldness and folly, refused to commune with him and with the five presbyters who with him had separated themselves from the church".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 43:44
verses.text: At the close of his letter he gives a list of the bishops who had come to Rome and condemned the silliness of Novatus, with their names and the parish over which each of them presided.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 43:45
verses.text: He mentions also those who did not come to Rome, but who expressed by letters their agreement with the vote of these bishops, giving their names and the cities from which they severally sent them".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 43:46
verses.text: Cornelius wrote these things to Fabius, bishop of Antioch.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 44:1
verses.text: Chapter XLIV.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 44:2
verses.text: —Dionysius' Account of Serapion.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 44:3
verses.text: To this same Fabius, who seemed to lean somewhat toward this schism, Dionysius of Alexandria also wrote an epistle.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 44:4
verses.text: He writes in this many other things concerning repentance, and relates the conflicts of those who had lately suffered martyrdom at Alexandria.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 44:5
verses.text: After the other account he mentions a certain wonderful fact, which deserves a place in this work.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 44:6
verses.text: It is as follows:.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 44:7
verses.text: "I will give thee this one example which occurred among us.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 44:8
verses.text: There was with us a certain Serapion, an aged believer who had lived for a long time blamelessly, but had fallen in the trial.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 44:9
verses.text: He besought often, but no one gave heed to him, because he had sacrificed.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 44:10
verses.text: But he became sick, and for three successive days continued speechless and senseless.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 44:11
verses.text: Having recovered somewhat on the fourth day he sent for his daughter's son, and said, How long do you detain me, my child? I beseech you, make haste, and absolve me speedily.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 44:12
verses.text: Call one of the presbyters to me.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 44:13
verses.text: And when he had said this, he became again speechless.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 44:14
verses.text: And the boy ran to the presbyter.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 44:15
verses.text: But it was night and he was sick, and therefore unable to come.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 44:16
verses.text: But as I had commanded that persons at the point of death, if they requested it, and especially if they had asked for it previously, should receive remission, that they might depart with a good hope, he gave the boy a small portion of the eucharist, telling him to soak it and let the drops fall into the old man's mouth.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 44:17
verses.text: The boy returned with it, and as he drew near, before he entered, Serapion again arousing, said, 'Thou art come, my child, and the presbyter could not come; but do quickly what he directed, and let me depart.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 44:18
verses.text: ' Then the boy soaked it and dropped it into his mouth.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 44:19
verses.text: And when he had swallowed a little, immediately he gave up the ghost.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 44:20
verses.text: Is it not evident that he was preserved and his life continued till he was absolved, and, his sin having been blotted out, he could be acknowledged for the many good deeds which he had done?"  Dionysius relates these things.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 45:1
verses.text: Chapter XLV.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 45:2
verses.text: —An Epistle of Dionysius to Novatus.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 45:3
verses.text: But let us see how the same man addressed Novatus when he was disturbing the Roman brotherhood.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 45:4
verses.text: As he pretended that some of the brethren were the occasion of his apostasy and schism, as if he had been forced by them to proceed as he had, observe the manner in which he writes to him:.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 45:5
verses.text: "Dionysius to his brother Novatus, greeting.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 45:6
verses.text: If, as thou sayest, thou hast been led on unwillingly, thou wilt prove this if thou retirest willingly.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 45:7
verses.text: For it were better to suffer everything, rather than divide the Church of God.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 45:8
verses.text: Even martyrdom for the sake of preventing division would not be less glorious than for refusing to worship idols.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 45:9
verses.text: Nay, to me it seems greater.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 45:10
verses.text: For in the one case a man suffers martyrdom for the sake of his own soul; in the other case in behalf of the entire Church.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 45:11
verses.text: And now if thou canst persuade or induce the brethren to come to unanimity, thy righteousness will be greater than thine error, and this will not be counted, but that will be praised.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 45:12
verses.text: But if thou canst not prevail with the disobedient, at least save thine own soul.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 45:13
verses.text: I pray that thou mayst fare well, maintaining peace in the Lord".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 45:14
verses.text: This he wrote to Novatus.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 46:1
verses.text: Chapter XLVI.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 46:2
verses.text: —Other Epistles of Dionysius.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 46:3
verses.text: He wrote also an epistle to the brethren in Egypt on Repentance.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 46:4
verses.text: In this he sets forth what seemed proper to him in regard to those who had fallen, and he describes the classes of transgressions.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 46:5
verses.text: There is extant also a private letter on Repentance, which he wrote to Conon, bishop of the parish of Hermopolis, and another of an admonitory character, to his flock at Alexandria.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 46:6
verses.text: Among them also is the one written to Origen on Martyrdom and to the brethren at Laodicea, of whom Thelymidres was bishop.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 46:7
verses.text: He likewise sent one on Repentance to the brethren in Armenia, of whom Merozanes was bishop.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 46:8
verses.text: Besides all these, he wrote to Cornelius of Rome, when he had received from him an epistle against Novatus.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 46:9
verses.text: He states in this that he had been invited by Helenus, bishop of Tarsus, in Cilicia, and the others who were with him, Firmilianus, bishop in Cappadocia, and Theoctistus, of Palestine, to meet them at the synod in Antioch, where some persons were endeavoring to establish the schism of Novatus.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 46:10
verses.text: Besides this he writes that he had been informed that Fabius had fallen asleep, and that Demetrianus had been appointed his successor in the episcopate of Antioch.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 46:11
verses.text: He writes also in these words concerning the bishop of Jerusalem: "For the blessed Alexander having been confined in prison, passed away happily".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 46:12
verses.text: In addition to this there is extant also a certain other diaconal epistle of Dionysius, sent to those in Rome through Hippolytus.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 46:13
verses.text: And he wrote another to them on Peace, and likewise on Repentance; and yet another to the confessors there who still held to the opinion of Novatus.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 46:14
verses.text: He sent two more to the same persons after they had returned to the Church.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VI 46:15
verses.text: And he communicated with many others by letters, which he has left behind him as a benefit in various ways to those who now diligently study his writings.
